docs.title: How to identify any aquatic animal
docs.description: This guide explains how to use the Aquaware API to identify aquatic animal species based on uploaded images. The API is available only to users with the Premium Subscription Tier (Tier 2).

docs.title: Get Alert Settings
docs.description: Alerts are only available in the Advanced or Premium plan. You can retrieve the current alert threshold settings for any water parameter within your environment. Alerts will notify you via email when thresholds are crossed, sent to your registered email address.

docs.title: Get All Values From Parameter
docs.description: The Get All Values From Parameter endpoint allows you to retrieve all water values for a specific parameter in an environment. This is useful for monitoring trends over time, for example, checking how the pH level or temperature of the water has changed.

docs.title: Save Alert Settings
docs.description: Alerts are only available in the Advanced or Premium plan. You can set threshold alerts for your water parameters through the API or directly in the app. Once set, alerts will notify you via email when a water parameter exceeds the defined threshold. The emails are sent to the account's registered email address.

docs.title: Quick Start Guide
docs.description: Welcome to Aquaware!

docs.title: Create an Account
docs.description: Creating an account with Aquaware is simple and can be done in just a few steps. You can either sign up directly through our website or, directly through the app.

docs.title: Login
docs.description: To access your Aquaware account, you can log in either through our website, the app or programmatically using our API. After logging in, you'll receive an api key, which is crucial for future authorization.

docs.title: Profile
docs.description: The Aquaware API allows you to fetch details about your user profile using the /api/users/profile endpoint. This endpoint provides essential user information, such as email, name, account creation date, API key, and subscription tier.

docs.title: Adding Water Parameters
docs.description: To maintain accurate records of your aquatic environment, you can upload water parameters directly to your environment. Below, you'll find all the details you need to get started, including how to use your API Key and Environment ID, as well as how to send data using a POST request.

docs.title: Create an Account
docs.description: Welcome to Aquaware! Creating an account is the first step to unlocking the full potential of our platform. Follow this guide to set up your account quickly and securely.

docs.title: Create an Environment
docs.description: What is an Environment?

docs.title: Explore the Dashboard
docs.description: Welcome to the Aquaware Dashboard! This is your central hub for managing your account, environments, and subscriptions. The dashboard is designed to make everything straightforward and intuitive, whether you‚Äôre updating your profile, adding water environments, or managing your plan.

docs.title: Thank You for Choosing Aquaware!
docs.description: I want to extend a heartfelt thank you for trusting Aquaware as your water monitoring solution. Your support means the world to me, and I am committed to continuously improving your experience with innovative features and reliable service.

docs.title: Use the Aquaware App
docs.description: Discover the convenience of monitoring your environments directly from your smartphone! With the Aquaware App, you can log in using the same credentials as your web dashboard and access all your environments in one place.

docs.title: Welcome to Aquaware
docs.description: I am thrilled to have you here! Aquaware is a platform created with love and care to make water monitoring and management simple, powerful, and accessible for everyone. Whether you‚Äôre a hobbyist, a researcher, professional, an organisation or someone just getting started, I am here to support your journey.

metadata.title: Nitrification Process
metadata.description: Understanding the nitrification process is essential for maintaining a healthy aquarium environment. This post explains how ammonia is converted to nitrites and nitrates, ensuring your aquatic life thrives.

blogPosts.content:
Understanding the nitrification process is essential for maintaining a healthy aquarium environment. This post explains how ammonia is converted to nitrites and nitrates, ensuring your aquatic life thrives.

<!-- truncate -->

# Understanding the Nitrification Process: A Friendly Dive into Aquatic Chemistry üåä

Nitrification might sound like a fancy term from your high school chemistry class, but it‚Äôs actually a super important process in the world of water ecosystems ‚Äì including your own aquarium! Let‚Äôs break it down step by step, keeping things simple and fun.

## What is Nitrification Anyway? ü§î

In a nutshell, nitrification is the process where ammonia (NH3) is converted into nitrites (NO2-) and then into nitrates (NO3-). This happens thanks to some tiny but mighty bacteria:

1. **Step 1: Ammonia to Nitrite**
   - Bacteria called _Nitrosomonas_ love munching on ammonia. Their "waste" product is nitrite.
2. **Step 2: Nitrite to Nitrate**
   - _Nitrobacter_ then takes the nitrite and converts it into nitrate. Nitrate is less harmful to aquatic life but still needs to be monitored.

:::info
Ammonia is toxic to fish even in small amounts, which is why nitrification is vital for a healthy aquarium!
:::

## Why Should You Care About Nitrification? üêü

If you‚Äôre an aquarium owner, this process is your best friend. Here‚Äôs why:

- **Keeps Your Fish Safe:** By transforming harmful ammonia into less toxic nitrate.
- **Promotes a Balanced Ecosystem:** It‚Äôs a key part of the nitrogen cycle, ensuring everything in your tank works in harmony.
- **Prevents Algae Blooms:** Controlling nitrate levels can stop those pesky green invaders.

## How to Support Nitrification in Your Aquarium üõ†Ô∏è

### 1. Cycle Your Tank Properly

Let your tank "cycle" before adding fish. This gives bacteria time to colonize and start the nitrification process.

:::tip
Test your water frequently during the cycling phase to monitor ammonia, nitrite, and nitrate levels.
:::

### 2. Add Beneficial Bacteria

You can jumpstart nitrification by introducing bottled bacteria. It‚Äôs like giving your tank a helpful little head start.

### 3. Maintain the Right Conditions

Bacteria are picky about their environment! Ensure:

- **Temperature:** Around 77¬∞F (25¬∞C) is ideal.
- **pH:** Keep it neutral to slightly alkaline (7.0-8.0).
- **Oxygen:** Good water flow and aeration help bacteria thrive.

## Troubleshooting Common Problems üö®

### High Ammonia Levels?

This could mean your tank is overstocked or you‚Äôre feeding too much. Cut back and consider a partial water change.

### Nitrite Spikes?

Be patient! It‚Äôs part of the cycle. In the meantime, keep testing and use a water conditioner if necessary.

### Stubborn Nitrate Levels?

Regular water changes and live plants can help reduce nitrates naturally.

:::note
A healthy tank means happy fish. Regular testing is your best friend when it comes to keeping water parameters in check!
:::

## Wrapping It Up üéâ

The nitrification process might be invisible, but its impact on aquatic life is huge. By understanding and supporting it, you‚Äôre setting the stage for a thriving aquarium. Remember, a little knowledge and care go a long way ‚Äì and your fish will thank you with their happy wiggles! üê†
